reviewText:
Brilliant concept. Can't see it being surpassed untill Hearts Of Iron 4 and even then it's gonna take about another 4 years to be honed with patches, expansions and DLC like this one has. The realism and historical authenticity, along with listening to the community as to what they actually want, has helped this game become a work of pure genuis. I've been playing computer games since Pong came out when I was a small child (showing my age here lol) and I've never come across a game that has so much depth and complexity.
Yet despite the complexity and high learning curve, once you are up and running it's relatively easy to play and more addictive than crack!
Then there's the very active community who are constantly modding it in many different directions and with the Black Ice mod, it's almost a sequel in itself and one of the best mods I've ever seen!
Pure genuis and that's not too strong a description for this incredible game. If you have even the slightest interest in WW2, put the work in and learn to play this game. As far as I'm concerned, it's a work of art and I could go on and on with superlatives all day.
It will take over your life and educate you even if you are a scholar on this period of history.
My only criticism is they bottled it when it came to the Holocaust!
It covers virtually everything else that went on in this terrible conflict like dropping the atomic bomb and carpet bombing civilian areas. So not including any mention of the Holocaust can't have been on moral grounds or they wouldn't have any of the aforementioned included in the game!  But the Holocaust isn't even mentioned in one of the hundreds of game events that updates the game as the war in it progresses. It's like it never even happened which is pandering to the Holocaust deniers in my opinion, or modern day wannabe Nazis as they should really be known as, or apologists for murderer's of old men, women, children and the disabled! However, I believe a mod will come along that does have the courage to tackle the genocide and by this I mean ALL of the genocide carried out by Stalin (one example; out of the 90,000 german prisoners taken at Stalingrad, only 6,000 ever returned), the Japanese and the factions in Yugoslavia, etc, as well as the Nazi genocide.
This game could have been a fantastic way of educating future generations studying this conflict, but not if the genocide goes totally ignored!
Still, this is a must play game for any serious computer gamer or WW2 buff.

reviewText:
8.5/10
Graphics? Meh.
Audio? Doesn't matter.
Game play? Yes sirree, we have a winner.
Like other paradox developed games, this is a Grand Strategy game on the Clausewitz Engine. It is set in world war II, and the leadup to that war. Build divisions of 2 to 5 Brigades, then organize those Divisions into corps, Armies, Army Groups, and Theaters. Carefully manage your production to keep dissent, supply, production, and upgrades in balance. Spy on your enemies, and keep yourself in power. This game is the micromanager's dream. The game is a real time strategy, but you can pause time to assess, rethink, and react. In fact, in a well set up game 80% lf the time you play will be spent paused, especially in the middle of a war, working out just how you'll move.
Don't want to micromanage? Give the AI control and master the individual elements without having to worry about the others. This game is propped up as a decent game on Gameplay, and Gameplay alone. If you don't like the graphics, wait till HoI 4 comes out, and you might get better graphics. As is, I reccomend this game to any strategy nerd out there, those who liked EU3, and the other paradox game should also find this a fitting final game in the four game quartet.

reviewText:
This is a good game.  However, be careful about purchasing the DLC.

As I discovered to my cost some of the DLC is badly programmed and is incompatible with other packages.

In particualr be careful about buying and installing 'Their Finest Hour' if you have either of the Dies Irae mods installed.  I made this mistake and it destroyed my enitre game making it completely unplayable until I was able to remove it again and repair the 103 critical files it had deleted in the process.

This is particularly easy to do as Steam are actually selling both the Dies Irae mods and Their Finest Hour in the same DLC bundle without printing a warning about the consequences of installing them.

The order of installation is also improtant if you want the game to work, even though this isn't explained in any of the DLC notes.

The following orders should work:

Either:-
1. Semper Fi
2. For The Motherland
3. Their Finest Hour.

or:
1. Semper Fi
2. For the Motherland
3. Dies Irae Götterdämmerung or Dies Irae Stars and Stripes

But not Their Finest Hour and Dies Irae or your game will refuse to load at all.

reviewText: I've tried all the major powers in Hearts of Iron: Germany, France, USSR, UK , US, and Japan. If you really want to develop an alternate history, you have to begin in 1936. The most difficult country to play as is Japan. The essential elements for success in this game are leadership and industrial capacity. Japan and France are both challenged in these areas. The easiest country to play is definitely the US. By begining in 1936, the US can concentrate on research and building industrial capacity BEFORE building units. To my mind, the worst mistake made by the Western powers was letting Republican Spain be conquered by the Fascists. If France, UK, and US had gauranteed Republican Spain's soverignty, they could never have been driven out of Europe in 1940. Worst case scenario, they could have retreated to Spain, and continued the war from there. Should the US joine the Allies early? No. Even if they have to support Spain alone, it is very important for the US to preserve it's freedom of action. In a game that I played as the US, Spain actually drifted to the Fascists BECAUSE the UK was bombing Spainish infrastructure. Defeat the Nationalists in Spain:yes. Destroy their country in the proxess:no.

reviewText:
As a veteran of this series I can say that this is the best out of all of them. For beginners this is an ideal entry to the series as you can have the AI control almost everything and you still get to influence what is happening and feel like a leader. For veterans like myself you can still micromanage as much as you want. The ability to build custom divisions adds another layer of depth. You get a special sense of satisfaction from moving your elite divisions to strategic points to break the enemy!

Like most paradox games this one has its bugs. Most of them have been ironed out however this game often crashes on me.
I found that weekly autosave and not using max speed during periods of intense warfare drasticly reduces that crash rate. Even after a crash starting from my last save is no big deal. This doesn't make me love this game any less, however the problem is still there.

All of the expansion packs are great and really deepen the experience. There is also an abundance of mods available that are easy to install.

reviewText:
The chronological successor to the Victoria series, what Hearts of Iron 3 lacks in graphical prowess it makes up for in Political, Technological, Historical, and Military depth. Even though the game significantly shortens the play period to 12 years, it makes every second of it enjoyable.

With the rise of the Commitern, Facist, and Allied powers, you take on the role of any country present in the WW2 period, and must make the choice of either going to the aid of Great Birtain and France, the invading Eastern Europe by Germnay's side, or crossing the Volga in a counterattack with your Soviet allies.

While it has the makings of great game, HOI 3 falls flat in some places. The shorter times span means that some situations repeat themselves, and the variety in playthrouhgs is diminished. Playing as a nation with a small military and population (i.e. Ireland) means you can't play a very active role in the war, and fighting the better armed and trained Axis or Allied forces would mean certain death.

8/10, a great game with it's share of faults, but still great.

reviewText:
I bought this game orginally without any previous experience of any other Paradox game, riding the wave of dissapointed and betrayed feelings after Rome 2:Total War's very rocky launch. I admired the fact that this apperaed to be nearest thing to actually commanding the conflict that one can ever hope to achieve, save for the people who actually fought in it. A very daunting, and perhaps even unfriendly game to beginners, it took me,  a realtively seasoned Strategy player of nearly all the Total War franchise, Company of Heroes and the even older Populous games, a very long time to figure out the games extraordinary complicity, and even today, I have only scratched the surface, after well over 200 hours of playtime. It is a flawed masterpiece however. The games AI, can be rather strange, commiting entire Heersgruppe's to deal with Norway, or in one instance, USA joining the Cominterm due to a pre-existing lend-lease treaty with Soviet Union. Also, those who have had their fill with singleplayer and dare venture forth to Multiplayer, will discover an ardous process of checking checksums, arranging private servers, and endless re-hosts,as Paradox did away with the Meta-server. However, Multiplayer can be very exciting and challenging, and even vetrans of singleplayer can be brought down by the novice in Multiplayer. Another great feature is mods, which deliver unparreled realism and depth, as well as hundreds of hours of playtime. To conclude, as I have said before, this is a flawed masterpiece, but certainly  a masterpiece of nontheless, doing something which, as far as I know, no other game franchise has done before, offering in depth realism of commanding any nation that existed between 1936-1948 in reagards to the Army(Airforce and Navy), Production, Diplomacy, Politics and Espionage. As well as that, it has thousands of real time generals, ministers, and commanders for each nation and party, even if you go a-historical, which is one of the games charms. A game that will never lose it's value or esteem.

TL/DR
Buy this game because Nazi nukes and Soviet cliches. Don't buy if your still stuck on the campaign for Call of Warfare 7: Battlefield Halo

9/10

reviewText:
This game is awesome.
You can play as any country before during and after World War II
It runs from 1936 to 1948, but you can play longer than that with mods.
You can control all aspects of the country, politics, diplomacy, espionage, military, everything.
There are multiple start dates that go from early 1936, to mid 1944.
Each start date has everything set up as it was in the world at that time.
The earlier you start, the more you can change history.
There are also multiple specfic scenarios to chose from, such as the Spanish civil war, the winter war, initial Japanese expansion into south east Asia, the Battle of the Buldge, etc.
There 3 factions in the game; The Allies *Capitalist, democracy* Britain is the leader, and is the only member other than France from the beginning.
The Comintern *Communist* The Soviets are the leader, and the only member from the start.
The Axis *Fascist* The Nazis are the leader, and the only member from the start.
Any country in the game can join any of the factions, as long as certain requirements are met.
One time I got America into the Axis, and it was a serious Where is your god now?" kind of moment.
Anyways

Can't recommend this game.

The research, diplomacy and espionage part of the game is really cool.  Creating customized corps is fun.

The downside is that managing wars(moving armies around) is very laborious.  Units can't really die unless being encircled so you basically have to orchestrate lines of units to do so.  The fighting style is Cruisader King or Europa Universalis.  Army, Navy and Air units are somehow hard to make them do what your want.
Can't say I've enjoyed giving control of my military to AI neither.

A lot of nice concepts with poor gameplay.

reviewText: This is a great game. There are two items of note about this game: it is both incredibly complex and deeply satisfying. With all the detail about World War Two that the game provides, nothing is more enjoyable than defying history. Maybe France won't fall to Germany in 1940, maybe Nationalist China can fight off the invasion from Japan (not so difficult actually), or maybe the Axis will emerge victorious. Some of those ideas may be more difficult than others, but regardless, after you understand this complex game, most of those ideas are possible to achieve.\nEuropa tries to model peace a bit too much, and thus there is less detail in war. Hearts of Iron is all about war. If you enjoy the great tactical and strategic battles of the second World War, this game is for you.

reviewText: Before I start, you need to have several pieces of dlc for this game, the dlc's stack so you cant just get the last one and be done with it. So you need for the motherland, their finest hour etc. Each dlc adds a bunch of new stuff and balances the game out. Now the game itself is complicated, as in there are many small parts to the game that interconnect. There are many minute details that you can put your attention to if you want it. There is also automation available. The core of this game is a WW2 warsimulator and it does a decent job at that, the map is devided into many small provinces that you fight over. Look at some screenshots to see what I mean. So for instance france is devided into 300 or more seperate provinces you can fight over. It's a game of numbers. You can command every division individually and every air wing too. So you can have rommel roll into denmark with tanks or guardian control a bunch of infantry divisions. Neither of these options are ideal but you can do what you want and go about it how you want. That is what makes the game fun for me.

reviewText: This game has a strong learning curve, but can be new player friendly. As I write I'm about 80.5 hours into this game and still learning things that would have been very beneficial hours ago. I keep discovering how much depth was put into this game the further I go, and it could not be much more enjoyable.\nThis is the ultimate strategy game, You will beed to be mindful of every front as well as the situations of your territories. reviewText:
Best of the best for what it was meant for, but it's for a select few
This game is the most sophisticated game I've ever seen. It takes it's strategy elements in the world map you are presented and lets you start off as certain countries in certain eras of pre-WWII and WWII itself. However...

As I said, this game is sophisticated. It's REALLY complicated, and as long as I've played I've barely been able to rename a few units and move 1 or 2 divisions / fleets. There are so many complicated aspects I could see myself getting into as I get older, but it's just too boring as it is, which I understand. I really respect what it's done and I'm glad it was done the way it was; with no flashy action all over the place all the time. That's not what this game is for or about. But, I just can't recommend this game to a general audience. It's for a very select group of people.

For me, I have to give a 6/10, but if I had to grade it's ability to do what it was intended to do, what it was supposed to do, 9-10/10. It's done what it was meant for with excellence, it's just myself not being able to get into this specific type of World Map domination strategy game.

reviewText: The reason why I don't recommend Hearts of Iron III is because of its various limitations which I do not think are overcome by its many features.\n\nThe game is set between 1936-1948.  That is, this is a World War II game.  If you enjoy WW2 lore and strategy games, this is not a bad game - the strengths of the game include technological advancements; the use of era-specific units; actual historical events that influence the overall experience (to make it more realistic in terms of both chronology and what are you going to do about that?"); and hardy diplomatic and espionage systems.  There are also levels of customization in terms of unit names
recommended: and other minor details.\n\nHearts of Iron III would be a totally awesome game if you could play it for much longer than just thirteen game years.  That is

then this one can give you some fun.  If you want to use the strategy elements of the game, then consider a different title from Paradox (like Europe Universalis III or IV or Crusader Kings II).  Even then, many of the strategic elements of Hearts of Iron III are not available in other Paradox titles except for other limited titles such as Victoria II.  Again, Paradox limits strategy players with period-specific games that do not allow for breaking from the mold and doing anything too free-form and significant (except when leading to a quick demise if you go too radical).

Just as a side note, the Hearts of Iron series (all three titles) is entirely limited to the World War II era.  Hearts of Iron II, however, had an interesting expansion pack that enabled a time frame into the 1950s where the USSR provided a fictional threat to the USA (similar to the storyline of Indiana Jones IV with the pseudo-history of fictional Cold War events or possibilities).  Hearts of Iron III, however, will stop you at 1948 - either you played as one of the major Axis Powers and took over Europe, or you played as one of the Allied Powers and prevented that.  Period.

--------

I wanted to provide some more technical or more specific reasons for why I would not recommend Hearts of Iron III to the general strategy gamer.

1)  Some technologies have twelve tiers to them.  That is, you will research one technology twelve times in order to cap it at Level 12/12.  Some technologies will require something like at least Level 3 of one technology in order to research a different technology.  This is really cool, of course.  However, you will find that unless you are either the United States or Germany, you will not be able to cap nearly any of these.  (As the USA or Germany, you might be able to cap just a few, even though there are several you'd probably like to.)  This is all fine if you just want to play a period-specific, relatively historically accurate game.  If you love strategy games in general, then this is a major let-down.

2)  If you want to modify Hearts of Iron III, then you probably should be (or will get to be) familiar with tweaking certain values in the text file of your savegame.  However, unlike Europa Universalis III or IV, Hearts of Iron III is not so simple to figure out.  And once you do, you will notice that there is not much you can significantly do to change your lot in the game world besides cheating to full capacity.  In all, it is ridiculous how limited this game is if you simply appreciate its strategic elements and also don't give a crap about historical accuracy.  But, of course, if you are a WW2 nut and just want historical accuracy above all else, then modifying the game should not be important to you, as this game definitely limits itself to that period faithfully!

reviewText:
This is a very good WW2 strategy game, but requires a bit of tinkering you can get the game to look fairly decent - the vanilla game is quite dark and dreary I found so I lightened the fog of war a bit, added coloured airbases etc and now it looks great - look for Nats Mods on the HOI3 mods forum:

https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/nats-mini-mods.643065/

Some of the DLC for this game conflicts with each other/doesnt work properly and it took me ages for me to get the game set up properly. Some of the German troops still dont have guns. I think it is some of the sprite packs that are at fault. You will need to go here to sort that:

https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/hoi-3-tfh-spritepack-fixes.644947/

For those with less time on their hands I have found Making History: The Great War to be very good alternative to this Paradox game but I have to admit that this game is far more detailed. The scenarios are fun where you can concentrate on the warfare, but the overall gameplay of a country in the main campaign is a bit overwhelming.

I think Heart of Iron 4 will be much better and easier to manage when it comes out in a few months. I would wait for that is you are looking to buy a game like this.

[Edit: Having said all that I've just played the Japanese scenario and had a lot of fun taking Singapore etc I think I am actually ready to dive into a full Japanese campaign whilst I wait for HOI4. Wish me luck!! It will be my first campaign ever tried properly - so far all my time has been spent on modding and playing the scenarios lol.]

reviewText:
Hearts of Iron III, in general, more of a wargame than a grand strategy game, and it is EXTREMELY HARD to get into, even for a grand strategy game, for a few main reasons:
1. The Order of Battle (OOB) system. It is very intimidating, and it's not unusual for you to spend half an hour or more organizing your army.
2. Poor UI. The UI for Hearts of Iron III is quite far from perfect, an example being there being a ton of mapmodes, with few even being useful, and a lack of shortcuts.
3. Relatively railroaded gameplay. Bringing up my wargame point from earlier, Hearts of Iron III has few sandbox elements outside of your country, and becomes extremely predictable very quickly, following the order on how the war begins, and the same people joining the same teams every time without player influence.
4. Terrible tutorial. The in-game tutorial" is basically ignorable and a complete waste of time that teaches you very little about the game; you're better off just watching a few YouTube videos as a new player.

reviewText: While Hearts of Iron III isn't for everyone, people should not be grossed out or write the game off based on its screenshots. Despite most of the game being looking at a map, it offers in depth detail into being the government and military of a country with total countrol. Most players find peacetime the most boring time throughout the game, this can be worse if your playing a country like the United States which doesn't enter WW2 for quite sometime. However, people may find it boring during this peace / build phase but if its not thought out well you'll be quickly regretting and possbily restarting because you found that phase unimportant. If you are like me, and love to add flavor of events and hard decisions during peacetime especially and wartime I would highly recommend the Black ICE mod. This mod adds hundereds of historical events and decisions which have major to minimal impact on the game. These events can both be helpful and hurt you but I feel like it makes the games events harder as its not always a easy decision. For those reasons and the diversity of units and divisions that can be accomplished give you a more fun and tough time, as the AI also build more diverse and recieve events just for them to keep them up to par with you. If anyone ever has any questions or thoughts about getting or already has the game and just wants to discuss anything about it I encourage you to message me. As stated above I strongly recommend this game in its vanilla state or its various mods such as Black ICE, HPP and August Storm.

You can play as litterally any country so you can choose how hard you make it for yourself. Conquer the world as luxembourg, iceland rules the waves anything, well not exactly.'

Whilst you have the freedom to be any country and do anything this game is as much a simulation as strategy. Maybe Belgium wants to invade Denmark but first you will need industry, good technology and an army. The rest of the world is not going to sit there either so be prepared from attack by Italy. This is what make it so addictive, you can see how  the war would have gone if you were in command of Germany and Diddn't attack Russia. Maybe you become communist whatever really...

So in a nut shell its great. If your PC can't handle it god knows why you bother buying games on computer because this is basically the lowest spec a decent game can have nowadays on computer. Maybe it's time to upgrade from intel cheseyum...

reviewText:
Simply amazing.

Pros -
You can play as any country, and swtich countires in a save.
Battles are very interesting and everything you do can affect them.
Many regions, too many!
Large amount of technology to research.
Large amount of units.
A lot to do, Many things that can change the history of World War 2.
A great World War 2 alternative history game!

Cons -
Has some bugs and glitches that weren't fixed.
Game crashes in some moments, especially when on fast game speed and a large country surrenders.
Game sometimes randomly crashes.
Cannot stop war in the middle, A pace treaty will reverse all lands conquered, meaning you cannot take parts of countires (unless included in the game, Like the occupation of Poland by SU and Germany)

Overall a must play game in my opinion!
Can't wait for HoI IV

reviewText:
Hours aren't accurate, since on Windows 10 I had to run in compatibility mode.
Anyways, in total I've probably spent 10-15 hours with this game and had hardly scratched the surface. I'm a former Starcraft Player, and while not competitive, Ive had a history with strategy games.

In comparison to strategy games I've played (Civ5, Age of Empires, SC2), Hearts Of Iron blows it out the water. This strategy game isn't for the casual and faint of heart however, since it is slow at the beginning and has a steep learning curve, hell I can hardly play the game without AI. The game's tutorial isn't much help, especially because I hate reading. I hope a new video/visual/interactive tutorial will be in IV to help new players and casuals like myself. I found the game extremely challenging, which in my case is a good thing, I liked the steep learning curve and time taken to actually be able to play. It makes the game play a lot more satisfying and interesting to play.

Overall this game is a 7/10, if it wasn't impossible to learn and had a better in game tutorial.

reviewText:
There is no read-me and no instructions for this game.  So you don't know what to do.  And I don't mean you're confused by some aspects of the game.  I mean you do not know how to interact with the game or accomplish anything.

Here was my experience.  I loaded the game, and it gave me a choice of a few games to play through.  I chose the easiest one that was suggested by the game as the easiest one, for beginners.  So I clicked on that one.

The game loads in.  I am looking at a map of Europe.  There are chits all over the map.  I can click on the chits and they make noises.  I don't know what the chits represent or how to interact with them.  I click on everything, push all the buttons on my keyboard, and can't do anything but make noises when I click on chits.

I thought it was a bug, so I quit and restarted.  Same thing.  I looked for a how-to-play or a manual or anything.  Nope.  I guess this is a game made for people that already knew how to play Hearts of Iron 1 or 2?

So the game is just looking at a map you can't interact with.

reviewText:
Paradox returns again with their newest WW2 Clunky Interface Simulators, bringing you the latest in paying money for minor graphical changes to the game.


I have not gotten into the depths of this game quite yet (Though I have more than my fair share in Darkest Hour multiplayer matches), but from what I have seen it is not too bad. A graphical update from Hearts of Iron II, Oil needs to be converted to Fuel, diplomacy affects trade, and automation out the wazoo.

The biggest change that this automation brings around is your theatres. You create a hierarchy of troops, and can give each part of the hierarchy a goal to accomplish, and the AI goes about doing it. The AI isn't too bad at this, but if you feel like you could do better, you can still manually select and control any divisions. My biggest problem with this system is how damn clunky it is to create the hierarchy. It could really use its own window to manage or something because individually selecting EACH AND EVERY DIVISION is ridiculous. However, once you have spent half your day organizing your armies, its pretty fun to manage. It makes it feel a lot more like you are a general of some form, assigning officers and giving them generic orders, and letting them do the micromanagement. But because its not required, you can still take care of any details you want and just let the AI deal with the rest.


Overall, I would definitely reccomend this game to someone who is interested in hearts of iron in general, and especially if you liked Hearts of Iron 2. However, if you feel like you are completely burnt out on Hoi2, this may not be for you. The way you manage government, technology, and diplomacy has changed a bit for the better, but the base game is still very similar.


Note: I have not played enough to say anything definitive about the AI.

reviewText:
This game is just an entirely broken mess of illogical game design. The long waits at reducing neutrality to zero in order to attack anyone is horribly thoughtout, and the fact that a cheat was built in to reduce your neutrality to 0 kind of makes me wonder what the devs were thinking. The diplomacy section is useless beyond belief. I attack Brazil (Axis) as Canada (Neutral) which sparks war with the USA (Allies) because for some unknown reason Axis and Allies don't automatically go to war. Who do I negotiate peace with in this weird situation? Not the US or Brazil...that would make the most sense...but Germany, the country I never attacked at all. I guess the glorious Fuhrer managed to pull a Cobra Commander and replace FDR. A+ for the weird alliance system that caues this to make abolutely no sense.

I was interested in this game solely because it allowed people to play as some other country other than the top dogs in WW2, and for that I give two thumbs up. But to have broken systems where said countries can do absolutely nothing in the game of any importance, and when they pull off a miracle and somehow do (taking GuanZhou from the enemy) said minnow has to give all the glory aka resources to the top dog because the UK is the Allied leader and they get all the territory.

If you want to be the top dogs, pick a different game. There are hundreds of them.

reviewText: Just to add a bit of backstory, I was actually gifted this game by a friend who loves it.  He got it for me so that we could play multiplayer together.  Unfortunatly we never got it to work because he owned a piece of DLC that I didn't.  But that's not why I'm not recommending this game, that's just a warning for those who plan on getting it to play multiplayer.  The reason is because this game is VERY difficult to learn.  The previous Paradox games I've played were very fun and somewhat user-friendly, so I was surprised that I couldn't say the same about this one.  It does come with a tutorial, however it is VERY long, and for some reason they tried to encorporate a small story into it making it much longer than neccessary, and honestly very off-putting and more boring than your average tutorial.  I enjoy a good story, but it's surprisingly difficult to pay attention to when you're also trying to memorize what all the complex options under the technology menu. Speaking of menus, this game has menus.  Lots and lots of menus.  Granted, it is organized very nicely, but it's still a lot to take in.  It takes some getting used to, but if you're dedicated enough you can learn it.  In fact, I think that applies to the entire game in general.  It's quite difficult to learn and even harder to master. While I know a lot of grand strategy game" fans will love it
date: I would NOT recommend this game to the average player.  However
recommended: if you've got a lot of time and you're looking for a complex strategy game

reviewText:
Let's start with the cons: this game is unstable, and will crash infrequently. This game is complex as hell and will likely overwhelm you right at the start. This game is also poorly designed from a UI standpoint and has far too many screens for management.
HOWEVER, the plus points of this game are: complex strategy, well thought-out balance and historicity, a solid combat and diplomatic system, and unbelievable replayability. By the time of this review, I have put 61 hours into the game, which I chose to start on the 1936 setting. I am now in 1939. Yeah. Add to this that the decisions I made completely changed how the war started and who's on which side, you can see where I'm going with this.

This game allows you to be Hitler. Or Stalin. Hell, you can even play as Luxembourg. Choose a country, build your armies (or not, but I would not recommend this choice), choose a side (or not) and play out this game. You can manage espionage, warfare, diplomacy, internal economics, trade, politics and technology (or you know, just put it on auto-manage).

Best Grand-Strategy I've played, even with its flaws.

9/10
